> I disagree, how about:
> 	try{
> 	    instance.someMethod(null);
> 	    fail("someMethod should not accept null");
> 	}catch(IllegalArgumentException e){
> 	    assertTrue("Client code should check for null arguments");

(Is that code correct?  Is there an assertTrue(String) method?)

Your call to fail(...) says that the method must throw an 
IllegalArgumentException when passed a null pointer.  

That is _not_ the same as saying that the caller must not pass in
null.


In your case, a caller is allowed to use the method to detect null 
pointers.  

In my case, a caller cannot expect any particular behavior.  (Maybe the 
method throws IllegalArgumentException.  Maybe it returns a bogus result.
Maybe it gets stuck in an endless loop.  Maybe it makes something else
fail 10000 calls later in another method.  Maybe it crashes the VM (via 
JNI).)



> > You can't test for any particular behavior from the callee
> > if the callee's behavior in the face of a null pointer is 
> > intentially left undefined (e.g., for flexibility in 
> > implementing an interface).)
> > 
> 
> The callee is the class being tested, the specifics for different
> implementations could be implemented
> in specific TestCases, 

Why test for behavior that is (intentionally) undefined?

Consider a method that is defined to return "an instance of some 
class implementing interface I."  In that specification, the
particular class is undefined.

If your implementation currently uses a class C, why test that 
the returned instance is of class C?  Why constrain yourself from
returning an instance of class D, as long as you still return
"an instance of some class implementing interface I"?

If you test for class C and treat tests as documentation, then 
that implies that a caller is allowed to depend on the fact that 
you return class C.  That is usually _not_ at all what you want.



> > (How can a test show that a caller is responsible for not
> > depending on certain current behavior of an implementation
> > that is not part of the interface contract?)
> > 
> 
> It can't, the caller's TestCase should do that. And possibly 

What caller?  That is, no caller necessarily even exists yet. 
So no, the caller's test case cannot do that.  

(And how could a test case for a caller detect whether that 
caller passes a null pointer to the called method?)

> documentation.
